results.title: Late Winter to Early Spring
results.brief_description: The threads of several simple stories - a young boy encounters an old man down on his luck, two couples meet - are wordlessly interwoven to evoke the rhythm of life in a public park (Fitzroy Gardens, Melbourne) in the passing age of winter and the youthful beauty of the approaching spring. Brealey acknowledged the influence of Arne Sucksdorff (Rhythm of a city) on his approach to this film. In ‘Sunday in Melbourne’ (1958) he took a different approach eschewing staged narrative.

results.title: Journey into tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Victorian Railways and Fortune Film Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the duplication and electrification of the Gippsland line to Yallourn and Traralgon. Shows its effect on the communities that look to the railway to bring them better living, more goods and greater service, and to take their products swiftly to market.

results.title: A Half million teenagers
results.brief_description: Studies the physiology aspects of venereal disease. Uses animation to show how the organisms of gonorrhea and syphilis enter and affect the body and how the diseases may be recognised. Stresses the need for treatment, pointing out that there is a cure for both diseases.

results.title: The Greatest game on earth
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Roland Beckett, Australian National Football Council and Melbourne Repertory Film Unit
results.brief_description: Ricky, who has recently arrived in Australia, sees his first game of Australian Rules Football when he follows the boys of his neighbourhood to the Melbourne Cricket Ground where Geelong is playing Collingwood. At first the atmosphere is strange and new, but the boy soon becomes a part of the enthusiastic crowd excited by the fast field play, high punt kicks, snap shots for goal and clever manoeuvres which comprise Australia’s national sport.

results.title: First aid
results.brief_description: A film of historic interest: an official training film produced for the War department in three parts. Part 1: emergency treatment of bleeding wounds, including self-administration. Covers the arterial system, pressure points and application of tournequets. Part 2: emergency treatment of broken bones. Part 3: covers methods of removing the wounded.

results.title: Farewell to childhood
results.creator_credit: Julian Roffman, Herbert Kerkow and Mental Health Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows common problems of adolescents and their parents. A moody 15 year-old girl clashes with her parents when they frustrate her efforts to “run her own life”. Mistakes by the parents, such as scolding her in front of her young escort, widen the rift between parents and daughter. Conditions improve when the girl’s teacher arranges a thorough discussion of adolescent problems, bringing more tolerance to both sides.

results.title: Don't lose your grip
results.creator_credit: R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1961 film illustrates safe methods for handling and storage of rolled steel joists, angles and plates in steel yards. Accompanied by an instructional narration, the film opens with a dramatised scene of an injured man caught beneath a steel beam due to the carelessness of a workmate. It shows footage of correct methods of stacking and storing steel beams, angles and plates, as well as demonstrating correct use of lifting equipment.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: A Demonstration of basic film techniques
results.brief_description: Designed to serve as a practical aid for teachers presenting a course in film appreciation. Experience has shown that one of the first barriers to be broken down in such a course is the students’ ignorance of the fact that a film is MADE, that it is the result of conscious decision by the film maker. Teachers may use it to demonstrate the more common shots in film making. They may use it to establish the idea of film editing - the joining together of separate shots into a meaningful unit. The film’s deficiencies and faults should serve as valuable teaching points during discussion after the film.

results.title: The Davis Cup, 1951
results.brief_description: The story of Australia’s fight to retain the world tennis premiership. The film covers the Interzone Final in Melbourne between Sweden and the USA and the Challenge Round in Sydney between the USA and Australia. Narrated by Michael Charlton and Peter Whitchurch.
